apart.core.node — Node Code¶

This module contains the code of a network node.

The Node class that it defines represents the core of the protocol implementation. It models all the behavior of the nodes (mainly message sending and receiving).

Most of the code is however defined in protected or private functions. These are also documented (but not included in this documentation by default). See the source code of class Node for more information.

This module also defines the ProtocolError exception.

exception apart.core.node.ProtocolError[source]¶

Bases: Exception

Exception raised when an error occurs in the protocol

class apart.core.node.Node(env, net, net_manager, node_id, neighbors)[source]¶

Bases: object

This class models a node in the network.

It builds and manages the internal state of the node. The main function run() is a SimPy process, and consist in an infinite loop where a message performs routing information and exchange messages with other nodes in the simulation

The constructor builds the internal state of the node, and register the run() method as a SimPy process. In particular, the constructor builds all routing tables, initializes the node’s src and dst values, its message spools and traffic rates counters

Parameters:
  • env (simpy.core.Environment) – the SimPy environment
  • net (Network) – the Network class instance which contains the node
  • net_manager (NetworManager) – the network manaer instance
  • node_id (int) – the node’s identity (an integer)
  • neighbors (int list) – list of neighbors nodes in the topology graph
display_node_table(table='rt+prt', constraints={})[source]¶

Print one or sevral of the node’s routing tables. Used for debug purposes

run()[source]¶

The node’s SimPy process, and main function.

The node SimPy process basically consists in an infinite loop (as long the attribute is_running of _net_manager is True) that makes batching round pass. That is, the loop begins with a SimPy timeout event of the duration of the batching time interval; then looks at incoming messages, and finally sends messages according to the batching strategy and the controlled traffic rate mechanism.

This function does not make the difference between the topology dissemination phase, and the oriented communication phase. It is just the core running function.

Yields:simpy.events.Timeout – simpy timeout events, one for each batching round (SimPy advances in the simulation by advancing in generators).
set_corruption_state(corrupted=True)[source]¶

Sets the corruption state of the node

start_oriented_communications(ocom_sessions=None)[source]¶

Public function, called by the network manager, to ask the node to start the oriented communication phase

Start an oriented communication is started with each receiver (and a different helper each) specified in ocom_sessions.

If the ocom_sessions argument is not provided, a random one is generated.

The ocom_sessions argument can be of the following form:
  • None: the node then chooses a random number of random communication partners
  • dict[r] = list(data) indicating thatthe node must send the list of data to each receiver r
  • dict[r] = n indicating that node must send n random pieces of data to each receiver r
  • (n_r, n_data [, n_data2]) indicating that the node must choose n_r random receivers, and send them n_data random messages each. If n_data2 is provided, then the node chooses a random number of messages to send in [n_data, n_data2], different for each receiver
Parameters:ocom_sessions (None or dict or tuple) – the sessions to initiate
batching_round¶

int – The current batching round the node is in

id¶

int – The node’s identity (an integer)

is_corrupted¶

bool – True is the node is corrupted

is_idle¶

bool – Becomes True when a node does not receive not send messages in a round.

neighbors¶

list of int – The node’s neighbor in the topology graph

pk¶

int – The node’s long-term public key

prt¶

PrevRoutingTable – The node’s previous hop routing table

rt¶

RoutingTables – The node’s routing table
